The Sutra of the Collection of the Past Activities of the Buddha, Scroll 33: Attaining Supreme Enlightenment At that time, the Bodhisattva, having already subdued all demonic enemies, pulled out all poisonous thorns and raised the victorious banner. Having sat on the vajra seat, he extinguished the contentious thoughts in the minds of all worldly beings.

After extinguishing disputes and fighting, internally and externally disciplined, with pure mind and conduct, in order to benefit all sentient beings in the world, in order to bring happiness to all sentient beings in the world, in order to cause all evil sentient beings to give rise to a compassionate mind, in order to sever the bonds and defilements of all evil sentient beings.

Having already eliminated the entanglements and coverings of sleepiness, the mind attains purity, the light manifests, and right mindfulness is perfected. One also teaches sentient beings to eliminate all the coverings of sleepiness.
Having already eliminated all frivolous behavior, one attains a pure mind without turbidity or confusion. One also teaches sentient beings to extinguish all frivolous thoughts and attain purity.
Having already severed all doubtful and remorseful thoughts, leaving behind dark and obstructed conduct, without doubt or hesitation regarding all good and evil dharmas, one attains a pure mind.
At that time, the Bodhisattva, having severed these five kinds of mind, gradually thinned out the afflictions.
Why is it so?
Because these five dharmas can cover and obstruct wisdom, cannot assist wisdom, and block the subtle and good path to nirvana.

Thus, all of them are completely abandoned, the mind of desire and unwholesome dharmas is left behind, the inner and outer are distinguished, contemplated and observed, the mind is single-pointedly tranquil and still, and one wishes to realize and experience the joy of entering the dharmas of the first meditation.
At that time, the Bodhisattva contemplated like this:

'I have now realized the first supreme mind, presently attained the subtle and wonderful dharma of bliss, and the mind is not heedless. I should correctly recollect and leave behind the village, and for those who practice in accordance with the dharma of the araá¹‡ya, I will cause them all to attain it.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, wishing to abandon all conceptual observation, purify the inner mind, and be without any conceptualization, arose from samÄdhi with a sense of joy and bliss, and practiced the Dharma of the second dhyÄna.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought like this:
'I have now given rise to these two enhanced minds, and have abandoned all evil and accomplished various practices, entering the second dhyÄna.

' At that time, the Bodhisattva, being disgusted with joy, practiced purity by abandoning [joy], with right mindfulness and right wisdom, experiencing the bliss of physical comfort, praised by the sages, abandoning all evil.
Having attained comfort, with such enhanced [mindfulness], he practiced the Dharma of the third dhyÄna.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought like this:
'This is my third enhanced mind, and I am a practitioner in the forest.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, wishing to abandon pleasure and abandon suffering, as before abandoning the discrimination of suffering and pleasure, without suffering and without pleasure, completely abandoning right mindfulness and purity, realized the Dharma of the fourth dhyÄna and practiced within it.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further contemplated:
This is my enhanced mind, the fourth presently seen Dharma, the practice of peaceful bliss, which I have already attained and realized, with an undistracted mind.
Good man!
You should be mindful and single-minded, practicing in the secluded tranquility of an araá¹‡ya.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, in this way single-minded, pure, without defilements, without obstructions, without veils, all suffering and afflictions completely extinguished, harmonious, pliant, able to perform various activities, already abiding in determination.

In the first watch of the night, he wished to perfect the spiritual powers and experience various spiritual realms, such as being able to transform one body into many bodies and then merge the many bodies back into one body. Having done so, he would disappear from above and reappear below, disappear from below and reappear above, freely manifesting and disappearing, and likewise appearing horizontally.
He could penetrate mountains, cliffs, and stone walls without obstruction, traveling as he wished, entering the walls and then emerging, and after emerging, re-entering.
It was like disappearing into a fog and then reappearing, and after appearing, disappearing again.
He could enter the earth as if it were water, walk on water as if it were earth, and appear and disappear in the sky like a flying bird.
He could emit smoke and flames, like a great bonfire.
With the greatest majesty and splendor of the sun and moon, he could reach out his hand to touch them, manifesting a long and great body up to the Brahma Heaven.
It was like a skilled craftsman or his apprentice taking pure gold and creating various vessels as they wish.
They also discern the high and low prices of those goods.

Just as a potter or a potter's apprentice, having prepared a lump of clay, places it on a wheel, and is able to produce whatever vessel they wish, and also knows its price. Just as a skilled carpenter or a carpenter's apprentice, having felled a tree, not rotten or dry, is able to produce whatever vessel they wish, and also knows its price.
Just as an ivory worker or an ivory worker's apprentice, having obtained fine ivory, is able to produce whatever vessel they wish and also knows its price.

In the same way, the bodhisattva is also like this. In this way, they accomplish a pure mind, a mind without turbidity or defilement, a mind without obstruction or hindrance, a mind without affliction or distress, a gentle and soft mind, a mind that accomplishes karmic activity, a mind of true tranquility and concentration.

In the first watch of the night, he cultivated and created various spiritual powers, accomplishing the mind of wisdom, manifesting various spiritual powers, namely transforming one body into many bodies, speaking in brief up to the body reaching the Brahma Heaven.
The bodhisattva's mind attained such tranquility, such purity, such clarity, such freedom from obscurations, eliminating all afflictions and troubles.
Having created the various karmas, the mind attained tranquility.

At that time, the bodhisattva in the first watch of the night again wished to realize and know the spiritual powers of past lives, accomplishing mental practices, wishing to know the various thoughts of others with his own mind.

Namely, the place of birth in one life, two lives, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, twenty, thirty, thirty-four, fifty, one hundred, two hundred, one thousand, ten thousand, innumerable millions, half a kalpa, a small kalpa, a medium kalpa, a great kalpa, innumerable small kalpas, medium kalpas, and great kalpas.

I was in such and such a place, with such and such a name, of such and such a clan, of such and such a kind, with such and such food and drink, with such and such happiness, with such and such a lifespan, and after death, I was reborn in such and such a place, and after that life, I died again.
At that time, the Bodhisattva knew various past lives through such characteristics and such practices, both his own and others'.

Moreover, one can know one's various past lives. It is like a person who leaves his own village and goes to another village. He knows where he sat on the road, where he walked, where he slept, where he spoke, and where he was silent.

When he arrives at that village, he knows the distance between the villages, and when traveling on the road, he knows where he walked, where he sat, and even where he slept and spoke or was silent, until he returns to his own village.
He then thinks and contemplates, knowing all that he left his own village and after some time arrived at that village.
He also knows that he stayed in a certain place for some time, walked for some time, sat for some time, spoke for some time, was silent for some time, and after some time, arrived at another town.
They also know how many times they have walked, sat, stood, lain down, spoken, and stopped in that place, and even when they have arrived at their own village, they know all this.
The bodhisattva is also like this.

With such a concentrated mind, a pure mind, a mind without defilements, such a soft mind, a mind without afflictions, a mind capable of action, in the first watch of the night, they attain the knowledge of past lives, correctly recollect and know, and accomplish the practice with a mind.ğŸ”½At that time, the bodhisattva, having contemplated and known their own birthplace and the birthplaces of others, namely, the places of birth in one country, up to the places of birth in countless, boundless hundreds of millions of eons,

At that time, the bodhisattva, according to the characteristics and teachings, heard the explanations in sequence, and knew the places where they were born, and also remembered the various places of birth of others.

The Bodhisattva, remembering these births, is able to have a mind of loving-kindness towards all sentient beings in various places, thinking: 'These are my relatives, these are outsiders. Having abandoned these relatives, I was born in such and such a place again. In this world and the other world, I revolve without rest.
Just like a wind-driven wheel, just like a plantain tree, it is definitely without substance. Afflictions are impermanent. This meaning is certain. The mind knows this.'

At that time, the Bodhisattva, with such a concentrated mind, such purity, such freedom from defilement, such freedom from vexation, such gentleness, able to perform tranquil practices, at midnight, wishing to accomplish and realize the divine ear, gave rise to this thought:
'Because of the divine ear, which is well-purified and surpasses the human ear,
I hear various sounds, namely, I hear the sounds of hell, the sounds of animals, the sounds of gods, the sounds of humans, distant sounds, and near sounds.'
It is like a village, town, country, or market, where someone ascends a high hall or tower and resides there.

Then another person with pure ears hears various sounds, namely, the sound of blowing conches, the sound of large drums, the sound of small drums, the sound of waist drums, the sound of lutes, the sound of guitars, the sound of flutes, reed organs, and zithers, various sounds.
Or he hears singing, or dancing, or laughing, or crying, or the sound of women, or the sound of men, or the sound of boys, or the sound of girls.
In this way, the bodhisattva, with his mind thus in concentration, pure, spotless, untroubled, clear, pliant, and workable, hears various sounds at midnight, up to the sounds of all the hells.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, in tranquil concentration, pure, without defilement or vexation, in the middle of the night, about to attain the heavenly eye surpassing human vision, saw all beings, those who had died and fallen, those who were reborn, beings in the upper realms, beings in the lower realms, beautiful beings, ugly beings, all beings who had fallen into evil paths, and all beings who were born in good destinies.
Whether walking or standing, or engaged in activities, he saw with his eyes all that was done,

and knew that such beings had engaged in impure physical actions, impure mental actions, slandered teachers and monks, or adhered to wrong views. Due to their wrong views, they created evil karma. For this reason, after leaving this life, they were reborn in the evil destinies of hell, and experienced various sufferings.
Such beings, due to their verbal actions, experience various sufferings in the evil destinies.
These beings, whose verbal actions are impure and who commit verbal evil actions, experience all kinds of suffering in the animal realm due to these causes and conditions.

These beings, who engage in physical evil actions and are replete with physical evil actions, due to these causes and conditions, create mental evil actions and are replete with mental evil actions, and even slander all sages, with various wrong views. Due to these wrong views, and the causes and conditions of wrong views, after death they abandon their bodies and fall into the realm of hungry ghosts, where they experience the sufferings of hungry ghosts.

Such beings, who engage in pure physical actions and pure verbal actions, do not slander sages, and who practice right views and create actions based on right views, due to these causes and conditions, after death they abandon their bodies and are reborn in the heavens.

If sentient beings create pure physical and verbal actions, complete in all aspects, without transgression or violation, not slandering the sages, with right views, due to the causes and conditions of such right views and actions, after death they leave the body and are reborn among humans.

In this way, the bodhisattva, with the pure divine eye surpassing that of humans, sees sentient beings, whether falling or being reborn, the sentient beings in the upper realms, the middle and lower sentient beings, the handsome and the ugly, those with fragrant bodies and those with foul-smelling bodies, those who reach the evil paths and those who reach the good paths, knowing the truth of their created karma as it is.

It is like a person who, in a noisy place such as a city, town, village, or market, ascends a high stage or building and sits there, using their pure divine eye to see the various people coming from the east, west, south, or north, or going in the opposite direction, coming or going, standing or sitting, moving about, sometimes going against the flow, sometimes going with the flow.

In the same way, the bodhisattva, in this way still and pure, without defilement or vexation, with a mind flexible in action, at midnight, sees the various sentient beings according to their karma receiving retribution, whether good or evil.
There is a verse that goes:ğŸ”½The suffering of hell beings is extreme, and animals eat each other,
Hungry ghosts are always afflicted with hunger and thirst, humans are in distress seeking wealth,
The heaviest suffering of separation from loved ones upon the exhaustion of heavenly rewards is beyond comparison.
All sentient beings, everywhere, have no time for joy.
This is called the deep abyss of the ghost of death and life, and also the bottom of the ocean of afflictions.
Sentient beings are drowning, with no way out, transmigrating back and forth.
Thus observing the five realms, with the heavenly eye one is able to see everywhere.
The beginning and end of afflictions are unreal, like breaking open a plantain leaf by leaf.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, with such a tranquil mind, such a pure mind, a mind free from defilements, thus far removed from all evil, with a mind that was gentle and pliable, fit for work, having attained tranquility.

At that time, at the end of the night, wishing to realize spiritual powers, he gave rise to the mind. Having given rise to the mind, he further knew the intentions of others, from where they arose, what they contemplated, and thoroughly knew them as they really are.

If there are sentient beings who give rise to a mind of desire and wish to engage in sexual activity, he truly knows this.ğŸ”½If there is a mind free from desire, far removed from desire, he truly realizes and knows this.ğŸ”½If there is a mind of anger, with anger giving rise, he truly knows this.
If there is a mind of disgust with anger, far removed from anger, he truly knows this.ğŸ”½If there is a mind of delusion, with a mind of delusion giving rise, he truly knows this.
If there is a mind of disgust with delusion, far removed from delusion, he truly knows this.

In this way, in brief, the mind of craving and the mind free from craving, up to the conditioned and the unconditioned, the lower and the higher realms, the still and the agitated, the vast and the narrow, the large and the small, the finite and the infinite, the superior and the non-superior, the attainment of concentration and the non-attainment of concentration, liberation and non-liberation, are all known as they truly are.

It is just as a man or a woman, when they are in the prime of youth, always delight in adorning their bodies. Having adorned their bodies, they sometimes look at themselves in a clean mirror or in clear water, and see their entire appearance.

In this way, in this way, the bodhisattva, in this way stilling their mind, in this way purifying it, in this way becoming free from defilements, in this way becoming free from vexations, flexible and well-balanced, able to engage in activities, having attained stillness, in the latter part of the night, with a pure mind, wishing to realize and attain the supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives, in this way their own mind and the minds of others are also like this.
From where does the mind arise? In what place does the mind arise? The mind and the mental factors, all known as they truly are.
If there is a mind of desire.
If it is a mind free from desire, they know it as it truly is.
Up to a mind liberated or not liberated, they know it as it truly is.
The bodhisattva attains such a mind, a pure mind, a mind without defilements, a mind free from all evil, a soft and pliable mind that can be made to work, and has already attained tranquility.
In the latter part of the night, he wishes to attain the supernormal knowledge of the destruction of defilements. He generates the mind of inner wisdom and thinks like this:

'These beings are sunk in the ocean of afflictions, namely, repeatedly being born, aging, sick, and dying. From here, they end their lives and go to another place. When they receive another birth, they will again experience all these sufferings, and are unable to know how to be free from these sufferings, namely, the sufferings of birth, aging, sickness, and death.'
Thinking like this:
'What expedient means should I now employ? How can I be free from these sufferings?'
What kind of karmic actions should be done, and how can one be liberated from birth, old age, sickness, and death, and reach the other shore?
And he spoke a verse, saying:
In the world, birth and death are like drowning in the ocean, dying again and again, and being reborn,
Entangled by old age, sickness, and various sufferings, the ignorant and deluded are unable to escape.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva spoke this verse, he further contemplated:
Where do old age, sickness, and death come from?
What causes and conditions give rise to old age, sickness, and death?
As the Bodhisattva was contemplating in this way, he knew that old age, sickness, and death exist because of birth. These old age, sickness, and death follow because there is birth.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:
Where does this birth come from?
For what causes and conditions
does birth exist?
As the Bodhisattva was contemplating in this way, he knew that birth exists because there is existence.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:ğŸ”½'From what does existence arise?
For what reasons does existence come to be?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that existence comes about due to grasping.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:ğŸ”½'From what does grasping arise?
For what reasons does grasping come to be?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that grasping comes about due to craving.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:ğŸ”½'From what does craving arise?
For what reasons does craving come to be?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that craving comes about due to feeling.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:ğŸ”½'From what does feeling arise?
For what reasons does feeling come to be?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that feeling comes about due to contact.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated:ğŸ”½'From what does this contact arise?
For what reasons does contact exist?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that it is due to the six sense bases that there is this contact.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated like this:ğŸ”½'From what do these six sense bases arise?
For what reasons are there these six sense bases?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that it is due to name-and-form that there are the six sense bases.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated like this:
'What are the reasons for this name-and-form?
From what does it arise?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that it is due to consciousness that there is name-and-form.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated like this:
'What are the reasons for this consciousness?
From what does it arise?'
Having contemplated in this way, the Bodhisattva knew that it is due to karmic formations that there is this consciousness.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated like this:
'What causes and conditions do these various activities have?
From what do they arise?'
The Bodhisattva, having contemplated like this, knew that because of ignorance, there are various activities.
The Bodhisattva further contemplated like this:

'Because of the condition of ignorance, there are various activities. Because of the condition of various activities, there is consciousness. Because of the condition of consciousness, there is name-and-form. Because of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases. Because of the six sense bases, there is contact. Because of contact, there is feeling. Because of feeling, there is craving. Because of craving, there is grasping. Because of grasping, there is becoming. Because of becoming, there is birth. Because of birth, there is old age. Because of old age, there is sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
These various sufferings each arise from causes and conditions.'
The Bodhisattva has never heard it from others, nor has he ever seen it himself. It gives rise to the eye of the Dharma, knowledge, intention, wisdom, and illumination.
The Bodhisattva further contemplates like this:
'What is absent, therefore old age, sickness, and death are absent?
What ceases, therefore old age, sickness, and death cease?'
The Bodhisattva thus contemplates and knows that because of non-arising, there is no old age, sickness, and death. Because of the cessation of arising, old age, sickness, and death cease.
The Bodhisattva further contemplates like this:
'What is absent, therefore this birth is absent?
What ceases, therefore this birth ceases?'
The Bodhisattva thus contemplates and knows that because of the absence of existence, this birth is absent. Because of the cessation of existence, this birth ceases.
The Bodhisattva further contemplates like this:ğŸ”½'What is absent, therefore all conditioned things are absent?
What ceases, therefore all conditioned things cease?'
The bodhisattva thinks like this and knows that because there is no ignorance, the various activities do not exist; because ignorance is extinguished, the various activities are extinguished.
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:

Because ignorance is extinguished, the various activities are extinguished; because the various activities are extinguished, consciousness also follows and is extinguished. In brief, up to birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress are all extinguished.
In this way, all suffering and its origin are completely extinguished.

The bodhisattva, in this way, in the past never heard of such a Dharma, but in this Dharma, the eye is born, knowledge is born, the mind is born, understanding is born, light is born, and wisdom is born.

At that time, the bodhisattva attained such a concentrated mind, such purity, such freedom from defilements, such a mind that is free from all afflictions and pliable, a mind capable of performing activities.

Having attained a tranquil mind, this is ignorance. Truly knowing, one also knows that ignorance arises due to such causes, and one also knows that ignorance ceases due to such conditions. Truly and accurately understanding this is the characteristic of the cessation and extinction of ignorance.

Having attained the right path, one truly knows, and so forth in brief, this is consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, becoming, birth, old age, sickness, and death, which one knows as they truly are.

This is the arising of all old age, sickness, and death. This is the cessation of all old age, sickness, and death. This is the path to the cessation of all old age, sickness, and death. Having attained cessation, one knows this.

Here, all taints are completely destroyed without remainder, cutting off all existence.
It is just as if, not far from a village or town or city, there is a pond, whose water is cool, sweet, pure, and clear, with no silt, always full to the brim, level with the banks.
And on the four sides of the banks, there are many trees, surrounding and adorning it.

In the pond there are also various creatures such as clams, snails, alligators, turtles, and fish, as well as many aquatic creatures such as rocks, sand, and various kinds of fish such as trout, croaker, anchovy, and moray eel, and makaras, swimming back and forth in the water, seeking food. Some are still, while others chase after each other.

There is a person with clear eyes on the shore, seeing through everything clearly, seeing all those creatures, knowing which are clams, which are snails, which are turtles, which are alligators, which are turtles, which are sand, which are rocks, which are fish, which are insects, and which are makaras, some seeking food, some dormant, some swimming back and forth, and some chasing after each other.

In the same way, the bodhisattva, with such a still mind, such purity, such freedom from defilements, such freedom from afflictions, such gentleness, able to perform various activities, has attained tranquility.
This is ignorance, to know it as it is in reality;
this is the arising of ignorance, this is the cessation of ignorance, this is the path to the cessation of ignorance, to know it as it is in reality.
In brief, all defilements here are completely extinguished without remainder.

At that time, when the Bodhisattva knew it was so, when he saw it was so, his mind was liberated from the defilement of sensuality, his mind was liberated from the defilement of existence, and his mind was liberated from the defilement of ignorance.

Having been liberated, he produced the wisdom of liberation, and having produced it, he knew: 'My birth has been exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not experience another existence.'

At that time, the great earth trembled in six ways, and all beings experienced the utmost bliss, with no suffering afflicting them.

At that time, there was not a single being who was angry, greedy, or deluded, nor did they give rise to thoughts of arrogance or self-importance. They were fearless, did not commit any offenses, and had no illnesses or afflictions.
Hungry and thirsty beings all became satiated, and intoxicated beings all became sober and did not drink any more alcohol.
The insane all regained their original minds, the blind all regained their sight, the deaf could hear, and those with incomplete limbs all became complete.
The poor all obtained treasures, the emaciated all became plump, and those imprisoned were all released with their shackles naturally coming apart.

The beings in the hells all escaped suffering, the frightened beings in the animal realm all had their fears extinguished, and the hungry ghosts all had their hunger and thirst end and were completely satisfied.
